issue_description:
# fetch_california_housing missing from the user guide

The fetch_california_housing function is missing from the dataset user guide:
http://scikit-learn.org/dev/datasets/index.html

issue_comments.body: Hey how would i update the documentation? Sorry for being a newbie

doc/datasets/index.rst

On 31 January 2018 at 20:57, Elliot Kang <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Hey how would i update the documentation?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/10555#issuecomment-361881718>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAEz6yA56PwmPnXNirHjPh_upaDuEGDlks5tQDkMgaJpZM4RzJoK>
> .
>
I think so, but it hasn't been closed so idk
@kkang2097 you didn't mention in your PR that it fixes this issue, so other users can't see that you've opened a PR. Also, your PR still needs work.
Hmm, okay. Is there any guides you can point me to for how to contribute to open source projects?
For the record: there is a WIP PR for this issue here: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/10560

Update: I already made the new description .rst file for the dataset, I just need to request a change to the index.rst file adding a reference to my proposed california_housing.rst file. Sorry, pretty hung up with classes / interviews right now. Will finish by the end of this week.

Update 2: So in my pull request I updated the index.rst to include the California Housing dataset. But in the last line of the .rst file I wrote :add: /sklearn/datasets/descr/california_housing.rst, which is the location I want to add my proposed new description. Do I need to put in a second pull request? I mean, how do I propose modifying/adding 2 files in a single pull request?

Hi @kkang2097, Not sure I completely understand your questions. 

> Do I need to put in a second pull request?

No. You should keep all your changes in one PR.

> modifying/adding 2 files in a single pull request

If you haven't used git before, you can learn the basics here : https://try.github.io/
Or use Github Desktop if you don't want to use the command line https://desktop.github.com/
Update: Have finished, and uploaded a pull request.
@kkang2097 has your PR been accepted or it still requires some modifications
Hey Guys, Is the work done?
Hi guys, I'm taking over this work as part of the sklearn sprint.

questions_generated: What is the purpose of the fetch_california_housing function in the scikit-learn repository?
Where should documentation for the fetch_california_housing function be added in the scikit-learn repository?
What is the process for contributing documentation changes in the scikit-learn repository?
How can multiple files be modified or added in a single pull request in Git?
What challenges might a new contributor face when updating documentation in an open-source project like scikit-learn?
What resources are available for new contributors to learn about contributing to scikit-learn?
golden_answers_generated: The fetch_california_housing function is used to load the California housing dataset, which is a popular dataset for regression tasks. It provides housing data from California based on the 1990 census, including features like median income, house age, and location coordinates.

The documentation for the fetch_california_housing function should be added to the 'doc/datasets/index.rst' file in the scikit-learn repository. This file serves as the index for dataset documentation, and the function should be included there to ensure it's part of the user guide.

To contribute documentation changes, you should fork the repository, create a new branch, make your changes in the appropriate files, and then submit a pull request. It's advised to keep all related changes in a single pull request and follow the contribution guidelines provided at http://scikit-learn.org/dev/developers/contributing.html.

In Git, you can modify or add multiple files in a single pull request by committing all the changes you want to include in your branch. Ensure you stage all the files you've modified or added before committing, and then push the changes to your fork. Finally, create a pull request from this branch to the main repository.

A new contributor might face challenges such as understanding the repository structure, learning how to properly format documentation, and using Git for version control. They might also need to understand the process for submitting pull requests and addressing review comments from maintainers.

New contributors can learn about contributing to scikit-learn by visiting the contribution guidelines at http://scikit-learn.org/dev/developers/contributing.html. Additionally, they can use resources like GitHub's desktop client for easier version control and tutorials like https://try.github.io/ for learning Git basics.
